column10: b"b' Fix for issue #149: CSRF protection URI whitelisting'"

b'b" Fix for issue #149 When developing applications that may have a web front end and an API front end (for example using Phil\'s REST server library) if you have CSRF protection enabled then POST API requests will fail because a non existent CSRF token can\'t be verified when the request is received. The changes here add a new config parameter \'csrf_exclude_uris\' which allows for URIs to be whitelisted from CSRF protection. I\'ve also updated the Security library documentation."'

column10: b'b\' I think I might have an idea about a more abstract way of doing this (the  issue)
column11: but I don\\\'t want another few hours wasted (by you
column12: me
column13: or anybody else who wants to get involved) only to get again to this point where we\\\'re not sure if this is what we really want. Creating the logic isn\\\'t that hard and it can be improved  fixed later
column14: if needed. But this is more of an architectural thing than anything else ... so
column15: lets first decide on wether we want to separate the logic into subdrivers or not. The main problem is that PDO is an abstraction layer in its own right
column16: which doesn\\\'t really fit in our two-level inheritance tree
column17: where each driver is supposed to represent a single database platform. ODBC is another such "driver" that we have
column18: but it\\\'s unlikely that we\\\'d add support for more (simply because there aren\\\'t many similar extensions). Let\\\'s be honest there\\\'s rarely a good reason to use either of them:1. You need to access a more "exotic" platform or one that\\\'s not supported on your OS.2. Your system administrator is being a jerk and has limited your options. For the first one
column19: ODBC has been a good friend of mine
column20: but I don\\\'t expect CI to have out-of-the-box support for e.g. Teradata even though it\\\'s more logical to want that instead of 3 MySQL drivers. And yet we have two MySQL drivers
column21: two MSSQL drivers and one for each other popular DB platform and we\\\'re trying to get all of them implemented all over again.Don\\\'t get me wrong PDO is an extremely popular tool and it\\\'s only logical to have it working flawlessly and I\\\'ve put a decent effort in that as well. I\\\'m just not sure wether adding another drivers\\\' layer just for PDO isn\\\'t a bit too far. So
column23: now the pros: We\\\'re trying to make everything as abstract as possible and so does PDO. I\\\'m not the one behind the current DB driver architecture
column24: but I\\\'d do it in a very similar manner even if I haven\\\'t seen it. Had it been put all in one (or 4 actually) class
column25: you can all imagine how hard it would be to read through it. It\\\'s just logical to have it that way and it\\\'s logical that PDO requires a similar architecture in order to be more easily maintanable. I\\\'ve already said that this might be going a bit too far
column26: but I also feel that it might be needed. Even I have a problem reading through the connection string building method that I made in #1032 (and I\\\'ve tried to make it as readable as possible). Sure

column33: I\\\'m not the sole developer working on it and CodeIgniter has always honored code readability (it has even been ridiculous at times).It\\\'s a 400+ line method and in order to get the PDO driver working flawlessly and keep the same architecture we\\\'ll have to have multiple of those. If I can\\\'t easily walk around my own code
column34: who else would be able to do it? And that pretty much sums it up. I\\\'ve tried to outline it fairly and as you can see
column35: I can\\\'t really say "yes" or "no". If somebody wants to vote though go for it. Just have it mind that I\\\'m talking about splitting it into subdrivers or not. I\\\'m not talking about this particular pull .\''

column10: b'b" I think PDO has a more limited scope than  can therefore be more tuned to each database. The whole point of having several database drivers is to fit the need of the user of the framework. It\'s a lot easier to fix an issue with a sub-driver
column11: than go through a superdriver to fix a database-specific bug.  PDO is just an abstraction of API
column12: not SQL
column13: so any one-for-all solution isn\'t going to be great. I think that sub-drivers are probably the easiest way to make the PDO driver more maintable
column14: and ultimately more useful. I think a lot of newer frameworks use PDO drivers exclusively
column15: so this is still pretty lightweight in comparision. Honestly
column16: I think it\'s time to think about deprecating the mysql driver
column17: but that\'s another matter. "'

column10: b'b" Let\'s try to get a working draft of what needs to be done to implement this issue. I\'m not saying this is necessarily how it _needs_ to be implemented
column11: but we have to start somewhere.1. Allow the loader to load files in different types of naming. We will try to load the files in the following order Load file using the same string passed in (i.e.   Load file using   Load file using all lowercase2. Here\'s where it gets tricky
column12: how exactly do we decide on how we instantiate the class? Do we do the same thing as above (i.e. instantiate the string given
column13: if doesn\'t exist
column14: instantiate ucfirst
column15: else all lower)?3. Add a log message when we have to lowercase the string given to  the class given. The problem I have with allowing these three different options is that there is a runtime performance hit. We have to check if a file exists and if a class exists before we can actually require a file or instantiate the class. If we force CI users to use a specific naming convention when using the loader
column16: then we can just require the file needed and instantiate the object without having to do that error checking first. The problem with that solution is that it doesn\'t give users flexibility to name their files how they like to. So I\'d propose
column17: we\'d force the naming convention of we require the file with the exact same name passed and instantiate the class with the exact same name passed in. So that way we still give users the ability to chooser their naming conventions
column18: but we don\'t have to go through the runtime performance ding of error checking. The only thing we\'d enforce users is that their class names and file names need to be the same
column19: but that\'s kind of the standard anyway in php. I know the performance ding isn\'t that much
column20: but little things add up. And what we can do for error checking is put the require and instantiation code in a  block so if there _was_ an error we can properly report it
column21: and  blocks don\'t hurt runtime performance unless an error occurs. This should lay a nice framework for what needs to be done
column22: so everybody else can modify these points until a final decision is made."'

column11: all possible detection methods will be used

column13: so it has the highest priority. The problem is that nginx doesn\'t seem to properly support it by default. This is how PATH_INFO works when you access an URI
column14: it is populated with any URL path data that is appended after the script name (in our case ). It\'s the same principle that enables you to utilize mod_rewrite for friendly URLs all redirects go to __ (where PATH_INFO must be set to _/something_. The key to your problem is this part of your nginx configuration: What that block does is to tell nginx to first try to access the literal representation of the requested URL path (i.e. \'test\' as a file); then if it is not found try to access it as a directory (again literal) \'test/\'; and of both fail simply call .The problem is that it doesn\'t pass anything to
column15: instead of redirecting it just executes it somewhere in the background without the existance of any data to populate in the PATH_INFO variable. And even that\'s not the real problem

column10: b'b" @WillieStevenson The cookie **domain** is not the same thing as the cookie **name**. People constantly confusing the two has resulted in that myth about underscores in cookie names no such problem exists. And it\'s the same with the dot character it\'s a perfectly valid one both in cookie names and the domains they\'re coupled with. The valid cookie name characters are defined by IETF\'s [RFC6265
column11: section 4.1.1]url  as:And [RFC2616
column12: section 2.2]url  defines the following:Meaning that the following are _all valid cookie name characters_: !#$%&\'*+-.0123456789ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ^_"'

column10: b'b" In the db query builder for mysql
column11: the where_in method silently does not include the \'where in\' clause when passed NULL as a value"'

column10: b'b" This seems like undesirable behavior. Logically
column11: one would think that this:  $this->db->where_in(\'some_column\'
column12: NULL); $this->db->update(\'test_table\'
column13: [\'other_column\'=>\'hello\']);  Would build a query like: UPDATE test_table SET test_column=\'hello\' WHERE some_column IN (NULL);  But it actually is much more dangerous:  UPDATE test_table SET test_column=\'hello\';  Thus updating every record in the database rather than those that match the WHERE IN clause.  Tested in version 3.1-stable"'

column10: b'b"   would match nothing (as in
column11: even NULL values wouldn\'t match)
column12: so this is just plain incorrect usage ..."'

column10: b'b" Yes
column11: it\'s incorrect usage
column12: but is a conceivably common error that shouldthrow an error. Silently ignoring and thus overwriting every record insomeone\'s table is a terrible idea. On Fri
column13: Nov 16
column15: 8:42 AM Andrey Andreev <notifications@wrote:>"'

column10: b'b" A conceivably possible mistake to make? Sure
column11: if you have some complex criteria-collecting logic
column12: maybe some sloppy programming would allow an to pass through where it shouldn\'t
column13: and one of those times it will happen to go into a call while there\'s no other criteria. But I could never see this as anything close to common.  What I\'m saying is that\'s a weak argument
column14: especially as a fallback to your original issue description. But I do agree that an accidental table wipe-out is a terrible outcome regardless of what lead to it. Do you have a patch proposal?"'

column10: b"b' Regardless of how common or not it might be to get a NULL passed into a where_in clause
column11: just silently dropping the where_in is a terrible idea. As for the solution
column12: you said it yourself: so if a NULL value is passed it should match nothing not potentially everything as it does now. And I should add that I believe in mysql at least
column13: WHERE IN (NULL) will throw an error. Which would be fine and definitely preferable to a table wipe.'"

column10: b'b"  You\'re saying that for the second time

column13: it executes without even a warning."'

column10: b'b" I\'m not arguing. You asked if I had a patch proposal.  I\'m proposing that where_in(\'field\'
column11: NULL) should generate a WHERE field IN (NULL)"'
